paper_metadata.title: Energy efficiency of state -of-the-art grinding processes

machine_info.material_processed: carbon steel and hardened cold -work steel

energy_data.energy_usage: In 2005, U.S. energy consumption due to grinding in manufacturing was estimated to be 17.6 TWh
energy_data.power_consumption: Spindle: 35 kW main spindle, Cooling lubricant pump: 18.5 kW for cooling lubrication and 11 kW for wheel cleaning
energy_data.measurement_method: Electrical power consumption of the whole machine, the drive system and different peripherals (such as cooling lubricant pumps, machine cooling system and mist separator) was measured and recorded with a temporal resolution of 100 ms using power monitoring devices and an Ethernet based data acquisition system.

kpi_metrics.efficiency: energetic process efficiency values were determined from values averaged over the whole process (i.e. not only during tool engagement) according to equation 3. The highest efficiency values occur for the highest values of 𝑄𝑄’𝑤𝑤 and 𝑣𝑣𝑐𝑐 which is attributable to the fact that the cutting force (and thus process power) rises with increasing feed rate and cutting speed.
other_kpis: Compressed air consumption was quantified as about 1.2 Nm³/min during processing and 0.4 Nm³/min (at 6 bar) in ‘operational’ condition

additional_notes: This paper presents an energetic evaluation of a modern CNC grinding machine and different grinding strategies, determining energy flows in different operating conditions and the characteristic power consumption of different machine components to evaluate the specific energy consumption of different grinding processes.
